subject: RE: [junit] Functionality Tests
msgSnippet: Hi -I ve recently worked on a project where the developers were using junit to write end-to-end tests and unless the DB was setup and the webservices were up
messageBody:
Hi -I've recently worked on a project where the developers were using junit
to write end-to-end tests and unless the DB was setup and the webservices
were up and running the tests would fail. My only problem with this was
they were stored in a source subdirectory called 'junit' implying that they
were actual unit tests.
I simply renamed the directory 'junit' to 'systemtest', and changed the
target names in ant's build.xml and everyone was happy - as far as I'm
concerned it does not make any difference that junit is being used to drive
system tests as long as its clear that they are system tests.

In your case, just keep what you have (system tests are as important as unit
tests) and start writing unit tests. Realistically you can't retro fit unit
tests to an existing project (time constraints), so just start adding unit
tests for any code you modify, bug fix etc.

Rgds,
Kevin.

Subject: [junit] Functionality Tests


Hy,

after some lurking on this list and following the discussions that happen
here I've come to the conclusion that the tests I'm currently running on
my project(s) are not really unit tests, although they use JUnit. As far
as I can tell they can be more accurately described as beeing
functionality tests as they usually test one use case end-to-end. That
came into beeing, since when I joined the project there were no tests at
all (aside from a few bit-rotted functionallity tests) and I started
writing what I thought at that time to be unit tests.

For example there are several tests that define a query (defined in OQL
(similar to SQL, but working on an object level)) that get's converted to
SQL, run on the database, the result retrieved, converted to java objects
and then my test checks wether the objects are exactly the objects that
were expected. I think I do have a rather clean idea how this could be
split into unit tests, only the system I'm testing is not modular enough
to allow this. (And to refactor it I'd need more tests, that I can't write
'till it's refactored ... a classical catch-22).

Fortunately there is some heavy refactoring in the future of this project
that will allow me to introduce more "real" unit tests ...

The reason I write all this down is that I'd like to hear wether anyone of
you has any experience/good advice for this kind of unit-test-free legacy
system. I'd be interested how you use functionality tests (in addition to
unit tests?) and wether anyone knows any tools that are better suited for
this kind of job than JUnit.

regards
Joachim Sauer
